awd_titl_txt: Planning: Eastern North and South Carolina STEM Teacher Corps Alliance Planning Meeting
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by forming a collaborative team – spanning multiple universities, K-12 districts, state-level education organizations, and non-profit entities across the predominantly rural Eastern Region of North and South Carolina – to recognize excellence and support professional leadership and growth opportunities for STEM teachers from traditional and alternative licensure pathways. This project supports a planning meeting with the team to develop a network that will recognize, elevate, and leverage the expertise of outstanding STEM teachers to promote professional learning for teachers from traditional and alternative licensure pathways throughout the region. The network will meet a significant need for more highly qualified STEM teachers, which will translate into high-level, equitable, and accessible learning opportunities for each student. Additionally, this project will provide an example of how to create a network of teacher leaders to support high-quality STEM instruction for not only Eastern North and South Carolina, but also with a focus on scalability. 

The scope of this project is to identify potential members of the regional collaborative team and hold a two day in person planning meeting with dedicated time to 1) listen to regional stakeholders potentially served by this project, 2) understand the unique needs across contexts, 3) examine existing resources, programs, and infrastructure, and 4) synthesize knowledge and understanding gained to co-construct the vision, mission, goals, and objectives for the Eastern North Carolina and South Carolina STEM Teacher Corps Alliance. An additional outcome of the meeting will be an outline of a project proposal to be submitted to NSF National STEM Teacher Corps Pilot Program. This project's design will advance understanding of how a network, in which outstanding STEM teachers work with a collaborative team, can elevate STEM teachers, collectively, throughout a region. The NSF National STEM Teacher Corps Pilot Program supports the elevation of the STEM teacher profession by selecting and recognizing outstanding STEM educators that advance equity in our Nation’s PreK –12 classrooms and providing professional development of STEM teachers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal for this project was to support a two-day learning exchange/planning meeting to bring together regional stakeholders who will collaborate to produce the foundation for an Eastern NC & SC STEM Teacher Corps Alliance. Objectives included (a) implementation of a needs assessment, (b) LOI development [RFP 24-577], (c) proposal development [RFP 24-577], and (d) proposal submission [RFP 24-577]. This project was a collaboration between multiple universities, K-12 districts, and non-profit entities across two states that aligned with multiple criteria noted for a Planning Proposal in the NSF PAPPG (24-1) and National STEM Teacher Corps Pilot Program (RFP 24-577). The large number of collaborators necessary to represent essential stakeholders and areas of expertise required an in-person meeting with dedicated time to: 1) listen to regional stakeholders potentially served by this project, 2) understand the unique needs across contexts , 3) examine existing resources, programs, and infrastructure, and 4) synthesize knowledge and understanding gained to co-construct the vision, mission, goals, and objectives for the Eastern NC/SC STEM Teacher Corps Alliance.

Specifically, the two-day, in-person learning exchange/planning meeting was designedto:

  • support initial conceptualization, planning, and collaboration activities focused on the recognition and retention of excellent STEM teachers from traditional and alternative licensure paths within the eastern regions of North and South Carolina,
  • support development of a larger-scale, research-focused proposal to be submitted to the National STEM Teacher Corps Pilot Program (RFP 24-577),
  • coordinate activities among a variety of STEM stakeholders using multidisciplinary approaches, context-specific expertise,and organizations, and
  • catalyze new collaborations that broaden the participation of individuals and organizations underrepresented in NSFawards portfolios (i.e., EPSCoR).

The two-day, in-person meeting was held at East Carolina University on Aug 12-13, 2024. This meeting included 22-24 participants on each day, representing a wide variety of critical stakeholders from the eastern regions of North and South Carolina. Stakeholder groups included:

  • Educator Preparation Program Administrators (e.g., Dean, Associate Dean, Dept Chair);
  • Mathematics & Mathematics Education Faculty from five institutions (East Carolina University, UNC-Greensboro, Elizabeth City State University, UNC-Wilmington, Coastal Carolina University, and College of Charleston);
  • North Carolina Dept of Public Instruction STEM Staff/Administration;
  • Public School District Administrators (e.g., Superintendent, Associate Superintendent);
  • Middle & High School Mathematics Teachers and Instructional Coaches;
  • Community College Faculty & Administration (e.g., Dept Chair, Instructors); and
  • Executive Director of STEM East Network.

As a result of the meeting, this project was able to: support initial conceptualization, planning, and collaboration activities focused on the recognition and retention of excellent STEM teachers from traditional and alternative licensure paths within the eastern regions of North and South Carolina, support development of a larger-scale, research-focused proposal to be submitted to the National STEM Teacher Corps Pilot Program (RFP 24-577), coordinate activities among a variety of STEM stakeholders using multidisciplinary approaches, context-specific expertise, and organizations, and catalyze new collaborations that broaden the participation of individuals and organizations underrepresented in NSF awards portfolios (i.e., EPSCoR).

Within the specific objectives:

(a) Implementation of a needs assessment - The project team created a Needs Assessment for District Adminstrators. Qualtrics was used to disseminate the Needs Assessment to school districts within the eastern region of North & South Carolina, as defined by the planning proposal. Due to the quick turn-around time, we received less responses than hoped, but the survey will be available for use as this work continues.

(b) Letter of Intent development [RFP 24-577] - After the completion of the planning meeting, the planning grant team worked with intended PI & co-PI's for a full proposal submission to draft a letter of intent that was submitted on 8/20/25.

(c) Proposal development [RFP 24-577] - After the planning meeting, conversations led to the identification of PI (Dr. Katie Schwartz) and co-PI's (Dr. Charity Cayton, Dr. Catharina Middleton, Dr. Heather Ries, and Dr. Andre Green) to form the group that developed a full grant proposal. The proposal included Letters of Collaboration/Support (n=15) from four IHEs, STEM Partners/Associations, and school districts.

(d) Proposal submission [RFP 24-577] - A full grant proposal for "The Eastern North and South Carolina Secondary Mathematics Teaching Alliance" was submitted prior to the Oct 1, 2024 deadline.


Last Modified: 04/24/2025
Modified by: Charity Cayton

(d) Proposal submission [RFP 24-577] - A full grant proposal for "The Eastern North and South Carolina Secondary Mathematics Teaching Alliance" was submitted prior to the Oct 1, 2024 deadline.					Last Modified: 04/24/2025
